candidates.title: Are These Towering Snow Walls in Massachusetts?
candidates.content:
Claim:
A photograph shows snow walls lining a highway in Massachusetts.
Rating:
Miscaptioned
About this rating
A photograph showing high walls of snow lining the edges of a highway has been circulating on the Internet since at least 2007. Popular memes have claimed (for humorous effect) that the picture was taken in Massachusetts, or (less homorously) in Canada:
The image actually captures a stretch of road near the Japanese city of Towada in Aomori prefecture.
The photograph was taken by Mihai Apostu and posted to his blog, "A Romanian in Japan," in April 2007:
Before heading down town we decided to take a walk up to Towada. On the way to Towada starting from April thh Gold Line Route is opened. This year's amount of snow was smaller than last year but the Hakkoda Walls are still big. Last year the walls of snow on both sides of the road were 9( nine) metres tall. This year there were only 6 metres of snow that guided us to Tsuta Onsen.
According to a sightseeing guide for the Aomori region of Japan, the Hakkoda Walls are quite a tourist attraction. Heavy snowfalls frequently close the corridor during the winter, but when the spring season approaches the Hakkoda Snowplow Squad gets to work and clears the road:
National Highway 103, commonly known as the Hakkoda-Towada Gold Line, is a popular sightseeing route in Aomori.8 km of this Hakkoda-Towada Gold Line stretching from Sukayu to Yachi Hot Springs is closed off in winter, but thanks to the efforts of the Hakkoda Snowplow Squad, they plow through the snow from both ends to meet at Kasamatsu Pass in late March, creating a stunning snow corridor.
In some places the walls of snow reach a height of 9 m, allowing visitors to enjoy magnificent views of the vivid blue of the sky contrasted against the white of the snow in perfect harmony.
The road opens to general traffic on April 1, but before this, a Hakkoda walk is held every year to walk through this snow corridor, and many people take part in the event.
candidates.description: The walls are formed with specially-designed snow plows.

result.explanation: The news caption is partially supported by the evidence.  Source 1 confirms that a photograph showing high walls of snow lining the edges of a highway exists and has circulated online. However, the source explicitly states that the photo was NOT taken in Massachusetts, but in Japan. The caption's claim of the location is incorrect, but its depiction of the image itself is accurate.
result.supporting_points: Source 1: The image actually captures a stretch of road near the Japanese city of Towada in Aomori prefecture. A photograph showing high walls of snow lining the edges of a highway has been circulating on the Internet.

final_result.explanation: The internal consistency check correctly identified that the image depicts a snowy highway but failed to pinpoint the location, resulting in a low confidence score. The external check provided strong evidence contradicting the caption's claim of the highway's location. While the external check confirmed the visual accuracy of the image's depiction of snow-lined highways, it explicitly stated the image was taken in Japan, not Massachusetts, significantly lowering the confidence in the caption's accuracy. Therefore, the caption is considered out of context because its claim about the location is factually incorrect, despite the accurate depiction of the scene. The discrepancy between internal and external checks stems from the inability of the internal check to identify the precise location, which was easily verified externally. The high confidence score reflects the strong external validation supporting the image's content while refuting the caption's location claim.
final_result.validation_summary: Internal check partially validated the image content but failed to verify the location. External check confirmed the image's depiction of a snow-covered highway but contradicted the caption's claim of the location being Massachusetts.  The caption is deemed out of context due to the inaccurate location information.
